author: GuzmanDiaz18
body:
## Steps to reproduce

1.- Run PowerShell 7 as administrator.
2.- Write the command: Install-Module -Name Az -AllowClobber -Force

## Expected behavior

Install new version of Az module.

## Actual behavior

![2020-08-26_13-42-43](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1861609/91343385-1918df00-e7a2-11ea-8f04-5647212f41c0.jpg)

## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19041
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

comments.author: jdhitsolutions
comments.body: I was able to run your command in 7.0.3 in a Windows Sandbox session with no error. Is it just the AZ module that gives you this error when installing?

comments.author: GuzmanDiaz18
comments.body:
> I was able to run your command in 7.0.3 in a Windows Sandbox session with no error. Is it just the AZ module that gives you this error when installing?

Yes, Can we do any additional tests? What commands can I run to do more additional tests?

comments.author: jdhitsolutions
comments.body:
Can you install any other module from the PowerShell Gallery?  You can try one of mine that is small.

```powershell
Install-Module PSTeachingTools -force
```

comments.author: GuzmanDiaz18
comments.body:
> Can you install any other module from the PowerShell Gallery? You can try one of mine that is small.
> 
> ```powershell
> Install-Module PSTeachingTools -force
> ```

I ran it and it didn't show me any error.

![2020-08-26_16-44-25](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1861609/91360129-7a00e100-e7bb-11ea-8dd1-2dbc2482ad69.jpg)

![Snag_1b16b14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1861609/91360277-c3513080-e7bb-11ea-84b5-dc2fbeff441f.png)

comments.author: jdhitsolutions
comments.body: That's good. I'd say try the AZ module again in a new session. If it fails again, then there must be something about that module and your computer. Because I had no problems installing the AZ module on different systems.

comments.author: GuzmanDiaz18
comments.body:
> That's good. I'd say try the AZ module again in a new session. If it fails again, then there must be something about that module and your computer. Because I had no problems installing the AZ module on different systems.

I did a test with the PowerShell 5 and it lets me run the command with no problem.

![2020-08-26_17-30-53](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1861609/91363319-ff878f80-e7c1-11ea-9eec-3f9af538e607.jpg)

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: You may need to update the version of your PowerShellGet module as well.

comments.author: jdhitsolutions
comments.body: It looks like he has the most current version of PowerShellGet. Run `Install-Module` with -Verbose and paste the results. You might find it easier to start a transcript, run the install verbosely, stop the transcript then past the verbose messages. Don't post a screen shot. That's too hard to read.

comments.author: derekscha
comments.body:
> 'C:\Users\Celso J. Guzman Diaz\OneDrive\Documentos\PowerShell\Modules'

I had the same issue. I am also redirecting my Documents folder to my OneDrive folder for replication. I had to remove the Modules folder manually and re-install all of my modules to get the Az module to install on a new machine. I'll be investigating options like [this one found on Stack](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56786702/how-to-change-powershell-default-module-installation-folder) to move where my profile gets the modules from. It would be a lot nicer if we could redirect the modules and scripts folders away from the Documents folder for reasons like this. Hope this helps others.

comments.author: GuzmanDiaz18
comments.body:
> > 'C:\Users\Celso J. Guzman Diaz\OneDrive\Documentos\PowerShell\Modules'
> 
> I had the same issue. I am also redirecting my Documents folder to my OneDrive folder for replication. I had to remove the Modules folder manually and re-install all of my modules to get the Az module to install on a new machine. I'll be investigating options like [this one found on Stack](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56786702/how-to-change-powershell-default-module-installation-folder) to move where my profile gets the modules from. It would be a lot nicer if we could redirect the modules and scripts folders away from the Documents folder for reasons like this. Hope this helps others.

If I already assumed it, I did everything you indicate at the time and it worked but this is a problem for a common user.

title: Index (zero based) must be greater than or equal to zero and less than the size of the argument list.
